question.title: Obtaining a concrete implementation of RepositorySystem
question.body:
From Maven Resolver javadocs:

Note that obtaining a concrete implementation of this interface (e.g. via dependency injection, service locator, etc.) is dependent on the application and its specific needs, please consult the online documentation for examples and directions on booting the system.

How do I obtain an instance of RepositorySystem? Where's that "online documentation" mentioned, which I assume to be an official part of the Maven Resolver product? Googling it does not reveal anything.

I'm not writing a Maven plugin so even if I could use Maven's own DI, stock examples won't work. I'm also interested in using the latest version of Aether and not rely on deprecated code, so e.g. DefaultServiceLocator should not be considered.

answers.body:
This is what Demos do, courtesy of another answer:

return new RepositorySystemSupplier() {
    @Override
    protected Map<String, TransporterFactory> createTransporterFactories() {
        Map<String, TransporterFactory> result = super.createTransporterFactories();
        result.put(
                JdkTransporterFactory.NAME,
                new JdkTransporterFactory(getChecksumExtractor(), getPathProcessor()));
        result.put(
                JettyTransporterFactory.NAME,
                new JettyTransporterFactory(getChecksumExtractor(), getPathProcessor()));
        return result;
    }
}.get();

With these two transporter factories (and corresponding dependencies) it can resolve remote artifacts. Then, RepositorySystemSession is defined as follows:

new SessionBuilderSupplier(system)
        .get()
        .withLocalRepositoryBaseDirectories(localRepository)
        .setRepositoryListener(null)
        .setTransferListener(null)
        .setConfigProperty("aether.generator.gpg.enabled", Boolean.FALSE.toString()).build()

The Aether project was archived years ago, which is probably why the old online docs are no longer accessible. You may find something relevant in the Wayback Machine. For example, there is this demo example on GitHub, from fifteen years ago.

Shouldn't you be using Maven Resolver instead, these days? More info here.

You can find demos here on GitHub. I have never used any of these, myself.

79785532.body: So they moved the code from one repo and into the another, but never really changed package naming and their contents. I guess I'll update tags.

I think that "eclipse aether was archived" bit is misguided, since all the classes used in the demo are still in org.eclipse.aether. So the same code base is still with us. Their demo does navigate the trouble of creating this class instance.
